subject: Mathematics
title: mathematical-reasoning

questions.text_html: Which of the following statements is a tautology?
questions.options_html:
1. \[\mathrm{p\vee(p\wedge q)}\]
  2. \[(\mathrm{p\wedge(p\to q))\to\,\sim q}\]
  3. \[\mathrm{p\to (p\wedge (p\to q))}\]
  4. \[(\mathrm{p\wedge q)\to(\sim (p)\to q)}\]

questions.text_html: Which of the following statement is a tautology?
questions.options_html:
1. \[(( \sim q) \wedge p) \wedge q\]
  2. \[(( \sim q) \wedge p) \wedge (p \wedge ( \sim p))\]
  3. \[(( \sim q) \wedge p) \vee (p \vee ( \sim p))\]
  4. \[(p \wedge q) \wedge ( \sim p \wedge q))\]

questions.text_html: Which of the following statements is a tautology ?
questions.options_html:
1. \[((\sim \mathrm{p}) \vee \mathrm{q}) \Rightarrow \mathrm{p}\]
  2. \[p \Rightarrow((\sim p) \vee q)\]
  3. \[((\sim p) \vee q) \Rightarrow q\]
  4. \[q \Rightarrow((\sim p) \vee q)\]

questions.text_html: The number of values of \(\mathrm{r} \in\{\mathrm{p}, \mathrm{q}, \sim \mathrm{p}, \sim \mathrm{q}\}\) for which \(((\mathrm{p} \wedge \mathrm{q}) \Rightarrow(\mathrm{r} \vee \mathrm{q})) \wedge((\mathrm{p} \wedge \mathrm{r}) \Rightarrow \mathrm{q})\) is a tautology, is :
questions.options_html:
1. 2
  2. 1
  3. 4
  4. 3

questions.text_html: Let \(\Delta ,\nabla \in \{ \wedge , \vee \} \) be such that \(\mathrm{(p \to q)\Delta (p\nabla q)}\) is a tautology. Then
questions.options_html:
1. \[\Delta = \vee ,\nabla = \vee \]
  2. \[\Delta = \vee ,\nabla = \wedge \]
  3. \[\Delta = \wedge ,\nabla = \wedge \]
  4. \[\Delta = \wedge ,\nabla = \vee \]

questions.text_html: Let \(\Delta\) \(\in\) {\(\wedge\), \(\vee\), \(\Rightarrow\), \(\Leftrightarrow\)} be such that (p \(\wedge\) q) \(\Delta\) ((p \(\vee\) q) \(\Rightarrow\) q) is a tautology. Then \(\Delta\) is equal to :
questions.options_html:
1. \[\wedge\]
  2. \[\vee\]
  3. \[\Rightarrow\]
  4. \[\Leftrightarrow\]

questions.text_html: Let \(\Delta\), \( abla \) \(\in\) {\(\wedge\), \(\vee\)} be such that p \( abla\) q \(\Rightarrow\) ((p \(\Delta\) q) \( abla\) r) is a tautology. Then (p \( abla\) q) \(\Delta\) r is logically equivalent to :
questions.options_html:
1. (p \[\Delta\] r) \[\vee\] q
  2. (p \[\Delta\] r) \[\wedge\] q
  3. (p \[\wedge\] r) \[\Delta\] q
  4. (p \[\nabla\] r) \[\wedge\] q

questions.text_html:
Let r \(\in\) {p, q, \(\sim\)p, \(\sim\)q} be such that the logical statement

r \(\vee\) (\(\sim\)p) \(\Rightarrow\) (p \(\wedge\) q) \(\vee\) r

is a tautology. Then r is equal to :
questions.options_html:
1. p
  2. q
  3. \[\sim\]p
  4. \[\sim\]q

questions.text_html:
The number of choices for \(\Delta \in \{ \wedge , \vee , \Rightarrow , \Leftrightarrow \} \), such that

\((p\Delta q) \Rightarrow ((p\Delta \sim q) \vee (( \sim p)\Delta q))\) is a tautology, is :
questions.options_html:
1. 1
  2. 2
  3. 3
  4. 4

questions.text_html:
\((\mathrm{S} 1)~(p \Rightarrow q) \vee(p \wedge(\sim q))\) is a tautology

\((\mathrm{S} 2)~((\sim p) \Rightarrow(\sim q)) \wedge((\sim p) \vee q)\) is a contradiction.

Then
questions.options_html:
1. only (S2) is correct
  2. both (S1) and (S2) are correct
  3. only (S1) is correct
  4. both (S1) and (S2) are wrong

questions.text_html:
Among the two statements

\((\mathrm{S} 1):(p \Rightarrow q) \wedge(p \wedge(\sim q))\) is a contradiction and

\((\mathrm{S} 2):(p \wedge q) \vee((\sim p) \wedge q) \vee(p \wedge(\sim q)) \vee((\sim p) \wedge(\sim q))\) is a tautology
questions.options_html:
1. both are false.
  2. only (S1) is true.
  3. both are true.
  4. only (S2) is true.

questions.text_html:
Among the statements

(S1) : \((p \Rightarrow q) \vee((\sim p) \wedge q)\) is a tautology

(S2) : \((q \Rightarrow p) \Rightarrow((\sim p) \wedge q)\) is a contradiction
questions.options_html:
1. neither (S1) and (S2) is True
  2. only (S2) is True
  3. both \[(\mathrm{S} 1)\] and \[(\mathrm{S} 2)\] are True
  4. only (S1) is True

questions.text_html: The negation of the expression \(q \vee \left( {( \sim \,q) \wedge p} \right)\) is equivalent to
questions.options_html:
1. \[( \sim \,p) \wedge ( \sim \,q)\]
  2. \[( \sim \,p) \vee q\]
  3. \[p \wedge ( \sim \,q)\]
  4. \[( \sim \,p) \vee ( \sim \,q)\]

questions.text_html: The statement \(\left( {p \wedge \left( { \sim q} \right)} \right) \Rightarrow \left( {p \Rightarrow \left( { \sim q} \right)} \right)\) is
questions.options_html:
1. a tautology
  2. equivalent to \[\left( { \sim p} \right) \vee \left( { \sim q} \right)\]
  3. a contradiction
  4. \[p \vee q\]

questions.text_html: Let p and q be two statements. Then \( \sim \left( {p \wedge (p \Rightarrow \, \sim q)} \right)\) is equivalent to
questions.options_html:
1. \[\left( { \sim p} \right) \vee q\]
  2. \[p \vee \left( {p \wedge ( \sim q)} \right)\]
  3. \[p \vee \left( {p \wedge q} \right)\]
  4. \[p \vee \left( {\left( { \sim p} \right) \wedge q} \right)\]

questions.text_html: The compound statement \(\left( { \sim (P \wedge Q)} \right) \vee \left( {( \sim P) \wedge Q} \right) \Rightarrow \left( {( \sim P) \wedge ( \sim Q)} \right)\) is equivalent to
questions.options_html:
1. \[(( \sim P) \vee Q) \wedge ( \sim Q)\]
  2. \[( \sim Q) \vee P\]
  3. \[(( \sim P) \vee Q) \wedge (( \sim Q) \vee P)\]
  4. \[( \sim P) \vee Q\]

questions.text_html: Negation of \(p \wedge(q \wedge \sim(p \wedge q))\) is :
questions.options_html:
1. \((\sim(p \wedge q)) \wedge q\)
  2. \((\sim(p \wedge q)) \vee p\)
  3. \(p \vee q\)
  4. \(\sim(p \vee q)\)

questions.text_html: The statement \((p \wedge(\sim q)) \vee((\sim p) \wedge q) \vee((\sim p) \wedge(\sim q))\) is equivalent to _________.
questions.options_html:
1. \[(\sim p) \vee(\sim q)\]
  2. \[p \vee(\sim q)\]
  3. \[\mathrm{p} \vee \mathrm{q}\]
  4. \[(\sim p) \vee q\]

questions.text_html: The statement \(\sim[p \vee(\sim(p \wedge q))]\) is equivalent to :
questions.options_html:
1. \[(\sim(p \wedge q)) \wedge q\]
  2. \[\sim(p \vee q)\]
  3. \[(p \wedge q) \wedge(\sim p)\]
  4. \[\sim(p \wedge q)\]

questions.text_html: The negation of the statement \((p \vee q) \wedge (q \vee ( \sim r))\) is :
questions.options_html:
1. \[(( \sim p) \vee r)) \wedge ( \sim q)\]
  2. \[(p \vee r) \wedge ( \sim q)\]
  3. \[(( \sim p) \vee ( \sim q)) \vee ( \sim r)\]
  4. \[(( \sim p) \vee ( \sim q)) \wedge ( \sim r)\]

questions.text_html: The negation of \((p \wedge(\sim q)) \vee(\sim p)\) is equivalent to :
questions.options_html:
1. \[p \wedge q\]
  2. \[p \wedge(\sim q)\]
  3. \[p \wedge(q \wedge(\sim p))\]
  4. \[p \vee(q \vee(\sim p))\]

questions.text_html: Statement \(\mathrm{(P \Rightarrow Q) \wedge(R \Rightarrow Q)}\) is logically equivalent to :
questions.options_html:
1. \[(P \Rightarrow R) \wedge(Q \Rightarrow R)\]
  2. \[(P \Rightarrow R) \vee(Q \Rightarrow R)\]
  3. \[(P \wedge R) \Rightarrow Q\]
  4. \[(P \vee R) \Rightarrow Q\]

questions.text_html: Negation of the Boolean statement (p \(\vee\) q) \(\Rightarrow\) ((\(\sim\) r) \(\vee\) p) is equivalent to :
questions.options_html:
1. p \[\wedge\] (\[\sim\] q) \[\wedge\] r
  2. (\[\sim\] p) \[\wedge\] (\[\sim\] q) \[\wedge\] r
  3. (\[\sim\] p) \[\wedge\] q \[\wedge\] r
  4. p \[\wedge\] q \[\wedge\] (\[\sim\] r)

questions.text_html: The boolean expression \(( \sim (p \wedge q)) \vee q\) is equivalent to :
questions.options_html:
1. \[q \to (p \wedge q)\]
  2. \[p \to q\]
  3. \[p \to (p \to q)\]
  4. \[p \to (p \vee q)\]

questions.text_html: The negation of the Boolean expression ((\(\sim\) q) \(\wedge\) p) \(\Rightarrow\) ((\(\sim\) p) \(\vee\) q) is logically equivalent to :
questions.options_html:
1. \[p \Rightarrow q\]
  2. \[q \Rightarrow p\]
  3. \[ \sim (p \Rightarrow q)\]
  4. \[ \sim (q \Rightarrow p)\]

questions.text_html:
The conditional statement

\(((p \wedge q) \to (( \sim p) \vee r)) \vee ((( \sim p) \vee r) \to (p \wedge q))\) is :
questions.options_html:
1. a tautology
  2. a contadiction
  3. equivalent to \[p \wedge q\]
  4. equivalent to \[( \sim p) \vee r\]

questions.text_html: The statement \((\sim(\mathrm{p} \Leftrightarrow \,\sim \mathrm{q})) \wedge \mathrm{q}\) is :
questions.options_html:
1. a tautology
  2. a contradiction
  3. equivalent to \[(p \Rightarrow q) \wedge q\]
  4. equivalent to \[(p \Rightarrow q) \wedge p\]

questions.options_html:
1. \[(\sim p) \wedge q\]
  2. \[p \wedge(\sim q)\]
  3. \[(\sim p) \vee(\sim q)\]
  4. \[(\sim p) \wedge(\sim q)\]

questions.text_html: \((p \wedge r) \Leftrightarrow(p \wedge(\sim q))\) is equivalent to \((\sim p)\) when \(r\) is
questions.options_html:
1. \[p\]
  2. \[\sim p\]
  3. \[q\]

questions.text_html: The statement \((p \wedge q) \Rightarrow(p \wedge r)\) is equivalent to :
questions.options_html:
1. \[q \Rightarrow(p \wedge r)\]
  2. \[p\Rightarrow(\mathrm{p} \wedge \mathrm{r})\]
  3. \[(\mathrm{p} \wedge \mathrm{r}) \Rightarrow(\mathrm{p} \wedge \mathrm{q})\]
  4. \[(p \wedge q) \Rightarrow r\]

questions.text_html:
Among the statements :

\((\mathrm{S} 1)~((\mathrm{p} \vee \mathrm{q}) \Rightarrow \mathrm{r}) \Leftrightarrow(\mathrm{p} \Rightarrow \mathrm{r})\)

\((\mathrm{S} 2)~((\mathrm{p} \vee \mathrm{q}) \Rightarrow \mathrm{r}) \Leftrightarrow((\mathrm{p} \Rightarrow \mathrm{r}) \vee(\mathrm{q} \Rightarrow \mathrm{r}))\)
questions.options_html:
1. only (S1) is a tautology
  2. neither (S1) nor (S2) is a tautology
  3. both (S1) and (S2) are tautologies
  4. only (S2) is a tautology

questions.text_html: The statement \(B \Rightarrow \left( {\left( { \sim A} \right) \vee B} \right)\) is equivalent to :
questions.options_html:
1. \[B \Rightarrow \left( {\left( { \sim A} \right) \Rightarrow B} \right)\]
  2. \[A \Rightarrow \left( {A \Leftrightarrow B} \right)\]
  3. \[A \Rightarrow \left( {\left( { \sim A} \right) \Rightarrow B} \right)\]
  4. \[B \Rightarrow \left( {A \Rightarrow B} \right)\]

questions.text_html: If \(p,q\) and \(r\) are three propositions, then which of the following combination of truth values of \(p,q\) and \(r\) makes the logical expression \(\left\{ {(p \vee q) \wedge \left( {( \sim p) \vee r} \right)} \right\} \to \left( {( \sim q) \vee r} \right)\) false?
questions.options_html:
1. \[p = F,q = T,r = F\]
  2. \[p = T,q = T,r = F\]
  3. \[p = T,q = F,r = T\]
  4. \[p = T,q = F,r = F\]

questions.text_html: The negation of the statement \(((A \wedge(B \vee C)) \Rightarrow(A \vee B)) \Rightarrow A\) is
questions.options_html:
1. equivalent to \[B ~\vee \sim C\]
  2. equivalent to \[\sim A\]
  3. equivalent to \[\sim C\]
  4. a fallacy

questions.text_html: The converse of \(((\sim p) \wedge q) \Rightarrow r\) is
questions.options_html:
1. \[((\sim p) \vee q) \Rightarrow r\]
  2. \[(\sim \mathrm{r}) \Rightarrow \mathrm{p} \wedge \mathrm{q}\]
  3. \[(\mathrm{p} \vee(\sim \mathrm{q})) \Rightarrow(\sim \mathrm{r})\]
  4. \[(\sim \mathrm{r}) \Rightarrow((\sim \mathrm{p}) \wedge \mathrm{q})\]

questions.text_html: Negation of \((p \Rightarrow q) \Rightarrow(q \Rightarrow p)\) is :
questions.options_html:
1. \[(\sim q) \wedge p\]
  2. \[q \wedge(\sim p)\]
  3. \[p \vee(\sim q)\]
  4. \[(\sim p) \vee q\]

questions.text_html: The maximum number of compound propositions, out of p\(\vee\)r\(\vee\)s, p\(\vee\)r\(\vee\)\(\sim\)s, p\(\vee\)\(\sim\)q\(\vee\)s, \(\sim\)p\(\vee\)\(\sim\)r\(\vee\)s, \(\sim\)p\(\vee\)\(\sim\)r\(\vee\)\(\sim\)s, \(\sim\)p\(\vee\)q\(\vee\)\(\sim\)s, q\(\vee\)r\(\vee\)\(\sim\)s, q\(\vee\)\(\sim\)r\(\vee\)\(\sim\)s, \(\sim\)p\(\vee\)\(\sim\)q\(\vee\)\(\sim\)s that can be made simultaneously true by an assignment of the truth values to p, q, r and s, is equal to __________.

Let p, q, r be three logical statements. Consider the compound statements

\({S_1}:(( \sim p) \vee q) \vee (( \sim p) \vee r)\) and

\({S_2}:p \to (q \vee r)\)

Then, which of the following is NOT true?
questions.options_html:
1. If S2 is True, then S1 is True
  2. If S2 is False, then S1 is False
  3. If S2 is False, then S1 is True
  4. If S1 is False, then S2 is False

questions.text_html:
Consider the following two propositions:

\(P1: \sim (p \to \sim q)\)

\(P2:(p \wedge \sim q) \wedge (( \sim p) \vee q)\)

If the proposition \(p \to (( \sim p) \vee q)\) is evaluated as FALSE, then :
questions.options_html:
1. P1 is TRUE and P2 is FALSE
  2. P1 is FALSE and P2 is TRUE
  3. Both P1 and P2 are FALSE
  4. Both P1 and P2 are TRUE

questions.text_html: If the truth value of the statement \((P \wedge(\sim R)) \rightarrow((\sim R) \wedge Q)\) is F, then the truth value of which of the following is \(\mathrm{F}\) ?
questions.options_html:
1. \[\mathrm{P} \vee \mathrm{Q} \rightarrow \,\sim \mathrm{R}\]
  2. \[\mathrm{R} \vee \mathrm{Q} \rightarrow \,\sim \mathrm{P}\]
  3. \[\sim(\mathrm{P} \vee \mathrm{Q}) \rightarrow \sim \mathrm{R}\]
  4. \[\sim(\mathrm{R} \vee \mathrm{Q}) \rightarrow \,\sim \mathrm{P}\]

questions.text_html: Let the operations \(*, \odot \in\{\wedge, \vee\}\). If \((\mathrm{p} * \mathrm{q}) \odot(\mathrm{p}\, \odot \sim \mathrm{q})\) is a tautology, then the ordered pair \((*, \odot)\) is :
questions.options_html:
1. \[(\vee, \wedge)\]
  2. \[(\vee, \vee)\]
  3. \[(\wedge, \wedge)\]
  4. \[(\wedge, \vee)\]

questions.text_html: The statement \((p \Rightarrow q) \vee(p \Rightarrow r)\) is NOT equivalent to
questions.options_html:
1. \[(p \wedge(\sim r)) \Rightarrow q\]
  2. \[(\sim q) \Rightarrow((\sim r) \vee p)\]
  3. \[p \Rightarrow(q \vee r)\]
  4. \[(p \wedge(\sim q)) \Rightarrow r\]

explanations: Q1: \(\begin{aligned} & \sim p \rightarrow q \equiv \sim(\sim p) \vee q \equiv p \vee q \\\\ & p \wedge q \rightarrow(\sim p \rightarrow q) \\\\ & \equiv p \wedge q \rightarrow(p \vee q) \\\\ & \equiv \sim(p \wedge q) \vee(p \vee q) \\\\ & \equiv(\sim p \vee \sim q) \vee(p \vee q) \\\\ & \equiv(\sim p \vee(p \vee q)) \vee(\sim q \vee(p \vee q)) \\\\ & \equiv T \vee T \\\\ & \equiv T\end{aligned}\)

Q2:

\(\because\) ((\(\sim\) q) \(\wedge\) p) \(\vee\) (p \(\vee\) (\(\sim\) p))

= (\(\sim\) q \(\wedge\) p) \(\vee\) t (t is tautology)

\(\equiv\) t

\(\therefore\) option (C) is correct.
Q3: Truth Table

Q1: \(((p \wedge q) \Rightarrow(r \vee q)) \wedge((p \wedge r) \Rightarrow q) \equiv T\) (given)

\(\equiv((\sim p \vee \sim q) \vee(r \vee q)) \wedge(\sim p \vee \sim r \vee q)\)

\(\equiv((\sim p \vee r) \vee(\sim q \vee q)) \wedge(\sim p \vee \sim r \vee q)\)

\(\equiv \sim p \vee \sim r \vee q\)

For above statement to be tautology

\(r\) can be \(\sim p\) or \(q\)

\(\therefore \) Two values of \(r\) are possible.

Q2: \((p \longrightarrow q) \Delta(p \nabla q)\)

\(\Rightarrow \left(p^{\prime} \vee q\right) \Delta(p \nabla q)\quad...(i)\)

\( \text { If } \Delta=v, \nabla=v \)

(i) becomes \(\left(p^{\prime} \vee q\right) \vee(p \vee q) \equiv T\)

Q3: \((p \vee q) \Rightarrow q\)

\( \begin{aligned} & \sim(p \vee q) \vee q \\\\ & =(\sim p \wedge \sim q) \vee q \\\\ & =(\sim p \vee q) \wedge(\sim q \vee q) \\\\ & =(\sim p \vee q) \wedge T \\\\ & =\sim p \vee q \end{aligned} \)

Now \((p \wedge q) \Delta(\sim p \vee q)\)

\( \begin{array}{cccccc} p & q & \sim p & p \wedge q & \sim p \vee q & (p \wedge q) \Delta(\sim p \vee q) \\ T & T & F & T & T & T \\ T & F & F & F & F & T \\ F & T & T & F & T & T \\ F & F & T & F & T & T \end{array} \)

\(\therefore \Delta=\Rightarrow\)

Q4: Case-I

If \(\nabla\) is same as \(\wedge\)

Then \((p \wedge q) \Rightarrow((p \Delta q) \wedge r)\)

is equivalent to \(\sim(p \wedge q) \vee\) \(((p \Delta q) \wedge r)\)

is equivalent to \((\sim(p \wedge q) \vee(p \Delta q)) \wedge(\sim(p \wedge\) \(q) \vee r)\)

Which cannot be a tautology

For both \(\Delta\) (i.e. \(\vee\) or \(\wedge\) )

Case-II

If \(\nabla\) is same as \(v\)

Then \((p \vee q) \Rightarrow((p \Delta q) \vee r)\) is equivalent to \(\sim(p \vee q) \vee(p \Delta q) \vee r\)

which can be a tautology if \(\Delta\) is also same as \(\vee\).

Hence both \(\Delta\) and \(\nabla\) are same as \(v\).

Now \((p \nabla q) \Delta r\) is equivalent to \((p \vee q \vee r)\).

Q5:

Clearly r must be equal to \(\sim\) p

\(\because\) \(\sim\) p \(\vee\) \(\sim\) p = \(\sim\) p

and (p \(\wedge\) q) \(\vee\) \(\sim\) p = p

\(\therefore\) \(\sim\) p \(\Rightarrow\) p = tautology.

Q6: Let \(x:(p \Delta q) \Rightarrow(p \Delta \sim q) \vee(\sim p \Delta q)\)

Case-I

When \(\Delta\) is same as \(v\)

Then \((p \Delta \sim q) \vee(\sim p \Delta q)\) becomes

\((p \vee \sim q) \vee(\sim p \vee q)\) which is always true, so \(x\) becomes a tautology.

Case-II

When \(\Delta\) is same as \(\wedge\)

Then \((p \wedge q) \Rightarrow(p \wedge \sim q) \vee(\sim p \wedge q)\)

If \(p \wedge q\) is \(T\), then \((p \wedge \sim q) \vee(\sim p \wedge q)\) is \(F\)

so \(x\) cannot be a tautology.

Case-III

When \(\Delta\) is same as \(\Rightarrow\)

Then \((p \Rightarrow \sim q) \vee(\sim p \Rightarrow q)\) is same at \((\sim p \vee \sim q) \vee\) \((p \vee q)\), which is always true, so \(x\) becomes a tautology.

Case-IV

When \(\Delta\) is same as \(\Leftrightarrow\)

Then \((p \Leftrightarrow q) \Rightarrow(p \Leftrightarrow \sim q) \vee(\sim p \Leftrightarrow q)\)

\(p \Leftrightarrow q\) is true when \(p\) and \(q\) have same truth values, then \(p \Leftrightarrow \sim q\) and \(\sim p \Leftrightarrow q\) both are false. Hence \(x\) cannot be a tautology.

So finally \(x\) can be \(\vee\) or \(\Rightarrow\).

Q1:

\(\therefore \mathrm{S} 1\) is correct.



\(\therefore \mathrm{S} 2\) is incorrect.

Q2: \( \begin{aligned} S_1: & (p \Rightarrow q) \wedge(p \wedge \sim q) \\\\ & \equiv(\sim p \vee q) \wedge(p \wedge \sim q) \\\\ & \equiv(\sim p \wedge p \wedge \sim q) \vee(q \wedge p \wedge \sim q) \\\\ & \equiv(f \wedge \sim q) \vee(f \wedge p) \\\\ & \equiv f \vee f \equiv f \\\\ S_2: & (p \wedge q) \vee(\sim p \wedge q) \vee(p \wedge \sim q) \vee(\sim p \wedge \sim q) \\\\ & \equiv((p \vee \sim p) \wedge q) \vee((p \vee \sim p) \wedge \sim q) \\\\ & \equiv(t \wedge q) \vee(t \wedge \sim q) \equiv q \vee \sim q \equiv t \end{aligned} \)

Q3: (S1) : \((p \Rightarrow q) \vee((\sim p) \wedge q)\)

\( \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline \mathrm{P} & \mathrm{Q} & \sim p & \sim p \wedge q & p \Rightarrow q & \begin{array}{c} (p \Rightarrow q) \vee \\ (\sim p \wedge q) \end{array} \\ \hline \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} \\ \hline \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} \\ \hline \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} \\ \hline \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} \\ \hline \end{array} \)

Here, for every value of components compound statement (last column) are not true. Hence, \(S_1\) is not a tautology.

\(S_2:(q \Rightarrow p) \Rightarrow((\sim p) \wedge q)\)

Q1: \(q \vee(\sim q \wedge p)\)

\(\Rightarrow(q \vee \sim q) \wedge(q \vee p)\)

\(\Rightarrow T \wedge(q \vee p)\)

\(\Rightarrow q \vee p\)

Now,

\(\sim(q \vee p)\)

\(=\sim q \wedge \sim p\)

Q2:

Making truth table (Let \((p \wedge \sim q) \Rightarrow(p \Rightarrow \sim q)=E\) )

\(p\) \(q\) \(\sim p\) \(\sim q\) \(p \wedge \sim q\) \(p \Rightarrow \sim q\) \(E\)
\(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)
\(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)
\(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)
\(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)

\(\therefore E\) is a tautology

Q3:

Making truth table \((E \equiv \sim(p \wedge(p \Rightarrow \sim q))\)

\(p\) \(q\) \(\sim p\) \(\sim q\) \(p \vee q\) \(p \wedge q\) \(\begin{aligned}p \Rightarrow p \sim q\end{aligned}\) \(p \wedge (p \Rightarrow \sim q)\) \(\mathrm{E}\)
\(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)
\(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\)
\(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)
\(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)

\(\&\)

\(\sim p \vee q\) \(p \vee(\sim p \wedge q)\) \(p \vee(p \wedge q)\) \(p \vee(p \wedge \sim q)\)
\(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)
\(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)
\(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\)
\(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\)

\(\therefore \sim(p \wedge(p \Rightarrow \sim q))\) is equivalent to \(\sim p \vee q\)

Other Method :

\( \sim \left( {p \vee \left( {p \to \sim q} \right.} \right)\)

\( = \sim p \vee \sim \left( {p \to \sim q} \right)\)

\( = \sim p \vee \sim \left( { \sim p \vee \sim q} \right)\)

\(= \sim p \vee \left( {p \wedge q} \right)\)

\( = \left( { \sim p \vee p} \right) \wedge \left( { \sim p \vee q} \right)\)

\( = t \wedge \left( { \sim p \vee q} \right)\)

\( = \sim p \vee q\)

Q4: \( \begin{aligned} &(\sim(P \wedge Q)) \vee((\sim P) \wedge Q) \Rightarrow((\sim P) \wedge(\sim Q)) \\\\ &(\sim P \vee \sim Q) \vee(\sim P \wedge Q) \Rightarrow(\sim P \wedge \sim Q) \\\\ & \Rightarrow(\sim P \vee \sim Q \vee \sim P) \wedge(\sim P \vee \sim Q \vee Q) \Rightarrow(\sim P \wedge \sim Q) \\\\ & \Rightarrow(\sim P \vee \sim Q) \wedge(T) \Rightarrow(\sim P \wedge \sim Q) \\\\ & \Rightarrow(\sim P \vee \sim Q) \Rightarrow(\sim P \wedge \sim Q) \\\\ & \Rightarrow \sim(\sim P \vee \sim Q) \vee(\sim P \wedge \sim Q) \\\\ & \Rightarrow(P \wedge Q) \vee(\sim P \wedge \sim Q) \Rightarrow(\sim P \vee Q) \wedge(\bullet Q \vee P) \end{aligned} \)

Q5:

The given statement is:

\(p \wedge (q \wedge \sim(p \wedge q))\)

We want to find the negation of this statement. To do that, we negate the whole expression:

\(\sim (p \wedge (q \wedge \sim(p \wedge q)))\)

Now, we will use De Morgan's laws to simplify the expression. De Morgan's laws state:

  1. \(\sim (A \wedge B) \equiv \sim A \vee \sim B\)
  2. \(\sim (A \vee B) \equiv \sim A \wedge \sim B\)

Applying the first De Morgan's law to the outer conjunction of the negated expression:

\(\sim p \vee \sim (q \wedge \sim (p \wedge q))\)

Now we need to address the inner conjunction \((q \wedge \sim (p \wedge q))\). To simplify this part of the expression, we again apply the first De Morgan's law:

\(\sim p \vee (\sim q \vee (p \wedge q))\)

Distribute the disjunction over the inner conjunction:

\( \sim \mathrm{p} \vee((\sim \mathrm{q} \vee \mathrm{p}) \wedge(\sim \mathrm{q} \vee \mathrm{q})) \)

Apply the law of excluded middle (A ∨ ¬A = T) on the last term:

\( \sim \mathrm{p} \vee(\sim \mathrm{q} \vee \mathrm{p}) \)

Apply De Morgan's law on the inner disjunction:

\( \sim(\mathrm{p} \wedge \mathrm{q}) \vee \mathrm{p} \)

Now, comparing this with the provided options, it matches with Option B :

\((\sim(p \wedge q)) \vee p\)

So, the negation of the given statement is :

\((\sim(p \wedge q)) \vee p\)
\(\sim (A \wedge B) \equiv \sim A \vee \sim B\)
\(\sim (A \vee B) \equiv \sim A \wedge \sim B\)

Q6: \( \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline \mathbf{p} & \mathbf{q} & \sim \mathbf{q} & \sim \mathbf{p} & \mathbf{p} \wedge \sim \mathbf{q} & \mathbf{\sim p} \wedge \mathbf{q} & \mathbf{\sim p} \wedge \mathbf{\sim q} \\ \hline T & T & F & F & F & F & F \\ T & F & T & F & T & F & F \\ F & T & F & T & F & T & F \\ F & F & T & T & F & F & T \\ \hline \end{array} \)

Using the truth table, we can see that the given statement is equivalent to \((\sim p) \vee(\sim q)\).

Alternate Method :

The given statement \((p \wedge(\sim q)) \vee((\sim p) \wedge q) \vee((\sim p) \wedge(\sim q))\) can be simplified using the following steps:

\( \begin{aligned} &(p \wedge(\sim q)) \vee((\sim p) \wedge q) \vee((\sim p) \wedge(\sim q)) \\\\ &= \left(p \wedge(\sim q)\right) \vee \left((\sim p) \wedge (q \vee (\sim q))\right) \\\\ &= \left(p \wedge(\sim q)\right) \vee \left((\sim p) \wedge t\right) \\\\ &= \left(p \wedge(\sim q)\right) \vee (\sim p) \\\\ &= (\sim p) \vee \left(p \wedge (\sim q)\right) \\\\ &= (\sim p \vee p) \wedge (\sim p \vee \sim q) \\\\ &= t \wedge (\sim p \vee \sim q) \\\\ &= \sim p \vee \sim q \end{aligned} \)

Therefore, the given statement is equivalent to \((\sim p) \vee (\sim q)\).

Q7: \( \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline p & q & p \wedge q & \sim(p \wedge q) & \begin{array}{c} p \vee \sim \\ (p \wedge q) \end{array} & \begin{array}{l} \sim[p \vee \sim \\ (p \wedge q)] \end{array} & p \vee q & \begin{array}{l} \sim(p \\ \vee q) \end{array} & \begin{array}{l} (p \wedge q) \wedge \\ \quad(\sim p) \end{array} \\ \hline \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} \\ \hline \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} \\ \hline \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} \\ \hline \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} \\ \hline \end{array} \)

\( \therefore \sim[p \vee(\sim(p \wedge q))]=\sim p \wedge(p \wedge q) \)

Q8: The negation of the statement \((p \vee q) \wedge(q \vee(\sim r))\) is

\( \begin{aligned} & =\sim[(p \vee q) \wedge(q \vee(\sim r))] \\\\ & =\sim[(p \vee q) \vee \sim(q \vee(\sim r)] \\\\ & =((\sim p) \wedge \sim q)) \vee((\sim q) \wedge r)) \end{aligned} \)

Apply distribution law,

\( \begin{aligned} & =\sim q \wedge((\sim p) \vee r)) \\\\ & =((\sim p) \vee r) \wedge(\sim q) \end{aligned} \)

Q9: \( \begin{aligned} & (p \wedge(\sim q)) \vee(\sim p) \\\\ & \equiv(p \vee \sim p) \wedge(\sim q \vee \sim p) \\\\ & \equiv \mathrm{T} \wedge(\sim q \vee \sim p) \\\\ & \equiv \sim q \vee \sim p \text { negation } p \wedge q \end{aligned} \)

Q10: We have, \((P \Rightarrow Q) \wedge(R \Rightarrow Q)\)

\( \begin{aligned} & \equiv(\sim P \vee Q) \wedge(\sim R \vee Q) \\\\ & \equiv(\sim P \wedge \sim R) \vee Q \text { (by distributive law) }\\\\ & \equiv \sim(P \vee R) \vee Q \\\\ & \equiv(P \vee R) \Rightarrow Q \end{aligned} \)

Q11:

Given,

(p \(\vee\) q) \(\Rightarrow\) ((\(\sim\) r) \(\vee\) p)

Negation is

\(\sim\) ((p \(\vee\) q) \(\Rightarrow\) (\(\sim\) r) \(\vee\) p))

= (p \(\vee\) q) \(\wedge\) \(\sim\) ((\(\sim\) r) \(\vee\) p)

= (p \(\vee\) q) \(\wedge\) (r \(\wedge\) \(\sim\) p)

[(p \(\wedge\) \(\sim\) p) \(\vee\) (q \(\wedge\) \(\sim\) p)] \(\wedge\) r

= q \(\wedge\) \(\sim\) p \(\wedge\) r

Q12:

Making truth table

p q p \( \wedge \) q \( \sim \) p \( \wedge \) q (\( \sim \) (p \( \wedge \) q)) \( \vee \) q p \( \vee \) q p \( \to \) q p \( \to \) (p \( \vee \) q)
T T T F T T T T
T F F T T T F T
F F F T T T T T
F F F T T F T T
Tautology Tautology

\(\therefore\) (\(\sim\) (p \(\wedge\) q)) \(\vee\) q \(\equiv\) p \(\to\) (p \(\vee\) q)

Q13:

Let \(S:(( \sim q) \wedge p) \Rightarrow (( \sim p) \vee q)\)

\( \Rightarrow S:\, \sim (( \sim q) \wedge p) \vee (( \sim p) \vee q)\)

\( \Rightarrow S:(q \vee ( \sim p)) \vee (( \sim p) \vee q)\)

\( \Rightarrow S:( \sim p) \vee q\)

\( \Rightarrow S:p \Rightarrow q\)

So, negation of S will be \( \sim (p \Rightarrow q)\)

Q14:

p q r \( \sim \) p A =
p \( \wedge \) q		 B =
\( \sim \) p \( \vee \) r		 C =
(A \( \to \) B)		 D =
(B \( \to \) A)		 C \( \vee \) D
T T T F T T T T T
T T F F T F T T T
T F T F F T T F T
T F F F F F T T T
F T T T F T T F T
F T F T F T T F T
F F T T F T T F T
F F F T F T T F T

\(\therefore\) Given statement is a tautology.

Q15:

\(\sim\) (p \( \Leftrightarrow \) \(\sim\) q) \(\wedge\) q

= (p \( \Leftrightarrow \) q) \(\wedge\) q

p q p \( \leftrightarrow \) q (p\( \to \) q) \( \wedge \) q (p \( \to \) q) (p \( \to \) q) \( \wedge \) q (p \( \to \) q) \( \wedge \) p
T T T T T T T
T F F F F F F
F T F F T T F
F F T F T F F

\(\therefore\) (\(\sim\) (p \( \Leftrightarrow \) \(\sim\) q)) \(\wedge\) q is equivalent to (p \( \Rightarrow \) q) \(\wedge\) p.

Q16:

\(p \Leftrightarrow (q \Rightarrow p)\)

\( \sim (p \Leftrightarrow (q \Leftrightarrow p))\)

\( \equiv p \Leftrightarrow \, \sim (q \Rightarrow p)\)

\( \equiv p \Leftrightarrow (q \wedge \sim p)\)

\( \equiv (p \Rightarrow (q \wedge \sim p)) \wedge ((q \wedge \sim p) \Rightarrow p))\)

\( \equiv ( \sim p \vee (q \wedge \sim p)) \wedge (( \sim q \vee p) \vee p))\)

\( \equiv (( \sim p \vee q) \wedge \sim p) \wedge ( \sim q \vee p)\)

\( \equiv \sim p \wedge ( \sim q \vee p)\)

\( \equiv ( \sim p \wedge \sim q) \vee ( \sim p \wedge p)\)

\( \equiv ( \sim p \wedge \sim q) \vee c\)

\( \equiv ( \sim p \wedge \sim q)\)

Q17:

The truth table

p q \( \sim \) p \( \sim \) q p \( \wedge \) q p \( \wedge \)  \( \sim \) q p \( \wedge \) q \( \Leftrightarrow \) p \( \wedge \) \( \sim \) q
T T F F T F F
T F F T F T F
F T T F F F T
F F T T F F T

Clearly p \(\wedge\) q \(\Leftrightarrow\) p \(\wedge\) \(\sim\) q \(\equiv\) \(\sim\) p

\(\therefore\) r = q

Q18:

\(p\) \(q\) \(r\) \(A = p\, \wedge q\) \(B = p\, \wedge r\) \(A \to B\) \(q \to B\) \(p \to B\) \(B \to A\) \(A \to r\)
T T T T T T T T T T
T F T F T T T T F T
F T T F F T F T T T
F F T F F T T T T T
T T F T F F F F T F
T F F F F T T F T T
F T F F F T F T T T
F F F F F T T T T T

\((p\, \wedge \,q) \Rightarrow (p\, \wedge \,r)\) is equivalent to \((p\, \wedge \,q) \Rightarrow r\)

Q1:

\({S1}:\left( {(p \vee q) \Rightarrow r} \right) \Leftrightarrow (p \Rightarrow r)\)

\({S2}:\left( {(p \vee q) \Rightarrow r} \right) \Leftrightarrow \left( {(p \Rightarrow r) \vee (q \Rightarrow r)} \right)\)

In \(S1:\) If \(p=F, q=T, r=F\) then \(S_1\) is false

In \(S2:\) If \(p=T, q=F, r=F\) then \(S_2\) is false

\(\therefore\) Neither S1 nor S2 is a tautology
Q2:

Q3:
\(\mathrm{p}\) \(\mathrm{q}\) \(\mathrm{r}\) \((p \vee q) \wedge((\sim p) \vee r)\) \(\sim \mathrm{q} \vee \mathrm{r}\)
\((1)\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)
\((2)\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\)
\((3)\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\)
\((4)\) \(\mathrm{T}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{F}\) \(\mathrm{T}\)

So, \((p \vee q) \wedge(\sim q \vee r) \rightarrow(\sim p \vee r)\) will be False.

Q4: \(((A \wedge(B \vee C)) \Rightarrow(A \vee B)) \Rightarrow A\)

\( \equiv \) \( [\sim(\mathrm{A} \wedge(\mathrm{B} \vee \mathrm{C})) \vee(\mathrm{A} \vee \mathrm{B})] \Rightarrow \mathrm{A} \)

\( \equiv \) \( \sim(\sim(A \wedge(B \vee C)) \vee(A \vee B)) \vee A \)

\( \equiv \) \( (A \wedge(B \vee C)) \wedge \sim(A \vee B) \vee A \)

\( \equiv \) \( (f \vee A)=A \)

\( \therefore \text { Negation of statement }=\sim A \)

Q5: Converse of \(((\sim p) \wedge q) \Rightarrow r\)

\( \begin{aligned} & \equiv \mathrm{r} \Rightarrow(\sim \mathrm{p} \wedge \mathrm{q}) \\\\ & \equiv \sim \mathrm{r} \vee(\sim \mathrm{p} \wedge \mathrm{q}) \\\\ & \equiv \sim \mathrm{r} \vee(\mathrm{p} \vee \sim \mathrm{q}) \equiv(\mathrm{p} \vee \sim \mathrm{q}) \Rightarrow \sim \mathrm{r} \end{aligned} \)

Q6: Given: \((p \rightarrow q) \rightarrow(q \rightarrow p)\)

Negation of above statement is :

\( \begin{aligned} & \sim[(p \rightarrow q) \rightarrow(q \rightarrow p)] \\\\ & \equiv \sim[\sim p \rightarrow q \wedge q \rightarrow p] \\\\ & \equiv p \rightarrow q \wedge \sim q \rightarrow p \\\\ & \equiv \sim p \vee q \wedge q \wedge \sim p] \\\\ & \equiv q \wedge(\sim p) \end{aligned} \)

Q7: There are total 9 compound propositions, out of which 6 contain \(\sim s\). So if we assign \(s\) as false, these 6 propositions will be true.

In remaining 3 compound propositions, two contain \(p\) and the third contains \(\sim r\). So if we assign \(p\) and \(r\) as true and false respectively, these 3 propositions will also be true.

Hence maximum number of propositions that can be true are 9.

Q8:

\({S_1}:( \sim p \vee q) \vee ( \sim p \vee r)\)

\( \cong ( \sim p \vee q \vee r)\)

\({S_2}: \sim p \vee (q \vee r)\)

Both are same

So, option (C) is incorrect.

Q9: Given \(p \rightarrow(\sim p \vee q)\) is false

\(\Rightarrow \sim p \vee q\) is false and \(p\) is true

Now \(p=\) True.

\(\sim T \vee q=F\)

\(F \vee q=F \Rightarrow q\) is false

\(P 1: \sim(T \rightarrow \sim F) \equiv \sim(T \rightarrow T) \equiv\) False.

\( \begin{aligned} P 2:(T \wedge \sim F) \wedge(\sim T \vee F) & \equiv(T \wedge T) \wedge(F \vee F) \\\\ & \equiv T \wedge F \equiv \text { False } \end{aligned} \)

Q10: \(\mathrm{X} \Rightarrow \mathrm{Y}\) is a false

when \(X\) is true and \(Y\) is false

So, \(\mathrm{P} \rightarrow \mathrm{T}, \mathrm{Q} \rightarrow \mathrm{F}, \mathrm{R} \rightarrow \mathrm{F}\)

(A) \(\mathrm{P} \vee \mathrm{Q} \rightarrow \sim \mathrm{R}\) is \(\mathrm{T}\)

(B) \(\mathrm{R} \vee \mathrm{Q} \rightarrow \sim \mathrm{P}\) is \(\mathrm{T}\)

(C) \(\sim(\mathrm{P} \vee \mathrm{Q}) \rightarrow \sim \mathrm{R}\) is \(\mathrm{T}\)

(D) \(\sim(\mathrm{R} \vee \mathrm{Q}) \rightarrow \sim \mathrm{P}\) is \(\mathrm{F}\)

Q11:

\( * ,\, \odot \in \{ \wedge ,\, \vee \} \)

Now for \((p * q) \odot (p \odot \sim q)\) is tautology

(A) \(( \vee , \wedge ):(p \vee q) \wedge (p \wedge \sim q)\) not a tautology

(B) \(( \vee , \vee ):(p \vee q) \vee (p \vee \sim q)\)

\( = P \vee T\) is tautology

(C) \(( \wedge , \wedge ):(p \wedge q) \wedge (p \wedge \sim q)\)

\( = (p \wedge p) \wedge (q \wedge \sim q) = p \wedge F\) not a tautology (Fallasy)

(D) \(( \wedge , \vee ):(p \wedge q) \vee (p \vee \sim q)\) not a tautology

Q12: \((\mathrm{A})(p \wedge(\sim r)) \Rightarrow q\)

\( \begin{aligned} &\sim(p \wedge \sim r) \vee q \\\\ &\equiv(\sim p \vee r) \vee q \\\\ &\equiv \sim p \vee(r \vee q) \\\\ &\equiv p \rightarrow(q \vee r) \\\\ &\equiv(p \Rightarrow q) \vee(p \Rightarrow r) \end{aligned} \)

(C) \(p \Rightarrow(q \vee r)\)

\( \begin{aligned} &\equiv \sim p \vee(q \vee r) \\\\ &\equiv(\sim p \vee q) \vee(\sim p \vee r) \\\\ &\equiv(p \rightarrow q) \vee(p \rightarrow r) \end{aligned} \)

(D) \((p \wedge \sim q) \Rightarrow r\)

\( \equiv p \Rightarrow(q \vee r) \)

\( \begin{aligned} & \equiv(p \Rightarrow q) \vee(p \Rightarrow r) \end{aligned} \)

subject: Mathematics
title: mathematical-reasoning

questions.text_html:
Consider the following statements:

P : I have fever

Q: I will not take medicine

\(\mathrm{R}\) : I will take rest.

The statement "If I have fever, then I will take medicine and I will take rest" is equivalent to :
questions.options_html:
1. \(((\sim P) \vee \sim Q) \wedge((\sim P) \vee \sim R)\)
  2. \((P \vee \sim Q) \wedge(P \vee \sim R)\)
  3. \(((\sim P) \vee \sim Q) \wedge((\sim P) \vee R)\)
  4. \((P \vee Q) \wedge((\sim P) \vee R)\)

questions.text_html: The number of ordered triplets of the truth values of \(p, q\) and \(r\) such that the truth value of the statement \((p \vee q) \wedge(p \vee r) \Rightarrow(q \vee r)\) is True, is equal to ___________.

Consider the following statements:

A : Rishi is a judge.

B : Rishi is honest.

C : Rishi is not arrogant.

The negation of the statement "if Rishi is a judge and he is not arrogant, then he is honest" is
questions.options_html:
1. B \[\to\] (A \[\vee\] C)
  2. (\[\sim\]B) \[\wedge\] (A \[\wedge\] C)
  3. B \[\to\] ((\[\sim\]A) \[\vee\] (\[\sim\]C))
  4. B \[\to\] (A \[\wedge\] C)

questions.text_html:
Consider the following statements:

P : Ramu is intelligent.

Q : Ramu is rich.

R : Ramu is not honest.

The negation of the statement "Ramu is intelligent and honest if and only if Ramu is not rich" can be expressed as:
questions.options_html:
1. \[((P \wedge(\sim R)) \wedge Q) \wedge((\sim Q) \wedge((\sim P) \vee R))\]
  2. \[((P \wedge R) \wedge Q) \vee((\sim Q) \wedge((\sim P) \vee(\sim R)))\]
  3. \[((P \wedge R) \wedge Q) \wedge((\sim Q) \wedge((\sim P) \vee(\sim R)))\]
  4. \[((P \wedge(\sim R)) \wedge Q) \vee((\sim Q) \wedge((\sim P) \vee R))\]

questions.text_html:
Let

\(\mathrm{p}\) : Ramesh listens to music.

\(\mathrm{q}\) : Ramesh is out of his village.

\(\mathrm{r}\) : It is Sunday.

\(\mathrm{s}\) : It is Saturday.

Then the statement "Ramesh listens to music only if he is in his village and it is Sunday or Saturday" can be expressed as
questions.options_html:
1. \[((\sim q) \wedge(r \vee s)) \Rightarrow p\]
  2. \[(\mathrm{q} \wedge(\mathrm{r} \vee \mathrm{s})) \Rightarrow \mathrm{p}\]
  3. \[p \Rightarrow(q \wedge(r \vee s))\]
  4. \[\mathrm{p} \Rightarrow((\sim \mathrm{q}) \wedge(\mathrm{r} \vee \mathrm{s}))\]

explanations:
Q1:

The given expression is

\(P \to \sim Q \wedge R\)

\( \equiv ( \sim P) \vee ( \sim Q \wedge R)\)

\( \equiv ( \sim P \vee \sim Q) \wedge ( \sim P \vee R)\)

Q2: \( \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline \boldsymbol{p} & \boldsymbol{q} & \boldsymbol{r} & \boldsymbol{p} \vee \boldsymbol{q} & \boldsymbol{p} \vee \boldsymbol{r} & \begin{array}{c} (\boldsymbol{p} \vee \boldsymbol{q}) \wedge \\ (\boldsymbol{p} \vee \boldsymbol{r}) \end{array} & \boldsymbol{q} \vee \boldsymbol{r} & \begin{array}{c} (\boldsymbol{p} \vee \boldsymbol{q}) \wedge(\boldsymbol{p} \vee \boldsymbol{r}) \\ \Rightarrow(\boldsymbol{q} \vee \boldsymbol{r}) \end{array} \\ \hline \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} \\ \hline \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} \\ \hline \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} \\ \hline \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} \\ \hline \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} \\ \hline \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} \\ \hline \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} & \mathrm{T} \\ \hline \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{T} \\ \hline \end{array} \)

Hence, the total number of ordered triplets are 7.

Q3:

\(\because\) Given statement is

(A \(\wedge\) C) \(\to\) B

Then its negation is

\(\sim\) {(A \(\wedge\) C) \(\to\) B}

or \(\sim\) {\(\sim\) (A \(\wedge\) C) \(\vee\) B}

\(\therefore\) (A \(\wedge\) C) \(\wedge\) (\(\sim\) B)

or (\(\sim\) B) \(\wedge\) (A \(\wedge\) C)

Q4:

P : Ramu is intelligent

Q : Ramu is rich

R : Ramu is not honest

Given statement, "Ramu is intelligent and honest if and only if Ramu is not rich"

\( = (P \wedge \sim R) \Leftrightarrow \, \sim Q\)

So, negation of the statement is

\( \sim [(P \wedge \sim R) \Leftrightarrow \, \sim Q]\)

\( = \sim [\{ \sim (P \wedge \sim R) \vee \, \sim Q\} \wedge \{ Q \vee (P \wedge \sim R)\} ]\)

\( = ((P \wedge \sim R) \wedge Q) \vee ( \sim Q \wedge ( \sim P \vee R))\)

Q5:

p : Ramesh listens to music

q : Ramesh is out of his village

r : It is Sunday

s : It is Saturday

p \(\to\) q conveys the same p only if q

Statement "Ramesh listens to music only if he is in his village and it is Sunday or Saturday"

\(p \Rightarrow (( \sim \,q)\, \wedge \,(r\, \vee \,s))\)
